description: Number of ways of dissecting a polygon into n quadrilaterals.
comments: The subsequence of primes begins: 2, 5, 6257, no more through a(100). - _Jonathan Vos Post_, Apr 08 2011
references: N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..100
F. Harary, E. M. Palmer and R. C. Read, On the cell-growth problem for arbitrary polygons, Discr. Math. 11 (1975), 371-389.
E. V. Konstantinova, A survey of the cell-growth problem and some its variations, Com 2 MaC-KOSEF, 2001.
mathematica: p=4; Table[(Binomial[(p-1)n, n]/(((p-2)n+1)((p-2)n+2)) + If[OddQ[n], If[OddQ[p], Binomial[(p-1)n/2, (n-1)/2]/n, (p+1)Binomial[((p-1)n-1)/2, (n-1)/2]/((p-2)n+2)], 3Binomial[(p-1)n/2, n/2]/((p-2)n+2)]+Plus @@ Map[EulerPhi[ # ]Binomial[((p-1)n+1)/#, (n-1)/# ]/((p-1)n+1)&, Complement[Divisors[GCD[p, n-1]], {1, 2}]])/2, {n, 1, 20}] (* _Robert A. Russell_, Dec 11 2004 *)
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
